jam.sort
Interface ThreadPriorities

public interface ThreadPriorities

Constants affecting thread priorities. A guide, taken from "Concurrent Programming in Java, 2nd Ed.", lists conventional priorities as in the table below. It also notes, however that particular JVM's may use the priorities differently, and may choose to ignore Thread.setPriority() altogether.

RangeUse
10Crisis management
7-9Interactive, event-driven
4-6IO-bound
2-3Background computation
1Run only if nothing else can

Version:
Apr 12, 2004
Author:
Dale Visser

Field Summary
static int MESSAGING
          Priority value for jam.VMECommunication.
static int NET
          Priority value for jam.sort.NetDaemon.
static int SORT
          Priority value for jam.sort.SortDaemon, which qualifies as background computation.
static int STORAGE
          Priority value for jam.sort.StorageDaemon, a relatively high priority thread for writing event data to disk.
 

Field Detail

NET

public static final int NET
Priority value for jam.sort.NetDaemon. Note that while this may seem like I/O, the arrival of a data packet is an important event that must be handled ASAP.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

MESSAGING

public static final int MESSAGING
Priority value for jam.VMECommunication. Messages from the VME are also events, but of a lower priority than data packets.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

STORAGE

public static final int STORAGE
Priority value for jam.sort.StorageDaemon, a relatively high priority thread for writing event data to disk.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

SORT

public static final int SORT
Priority value for jam.sort.SortDaemon, which qualifies as background computation.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
